results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
This film shows suburban street scenes, a trip to the country and a visit to an animal shelter. There are good examples of 1960s fashion, suburban architecture and cars reflective of the era.

The film opens with Maurie and friends playfully posing with each other and performing for the camera in a tree-lined suburban street, possibly in Albert Park.

The friends all get into a Morris Major Elite (1962-1964) waving as they drive down the street past a Chrysler AP2 Royal (1958-1961). Single-story terrace houses can be seen in the background.

The family makes a stop-over at a cat and kitten shelter. A handwritten sign scrawled across the side of the building reads: “All cats and kittens in the hostel are stray and unwanted. Their health cannot be guaranteed. Please consult your vet and have your cat immunised immediately”. Beside the writing there is another sign reading “Kindly give a donation thank you”. Val plays with a kitten and presumably adopts it as she carries it into their car.

Families enjoy a couple of trips to the country, including a picnic under pine trees. A small boy attempts to climb one of the trees with hands-on assistance from Maurie. Val swings from a branch, flailing her legs comically. Lunch is cooked on a portable tripod-style wood-fuelled barbeque, while people sit in plastic banana lounges and picnic chairs. There is general banter and typical outdoor revelry among the friends. A large, non-functioning steam train serves as an improvised playground for the children.

Originally made on 8mm film.

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmão Film Collection]
results.material_description:
30 x reels 8mm film
Super 8mm and regular 8mm film collection, anotated list of content provided by donor see documents references window.
results.brief_description:
Kirsty Sword Gusmao AO is and Australian-East Timorese activist who served as the First Lady of East Timor from 2002 until 2007. She was married to Xanana Gusmao, Prime Minister and former President of Timor-Leste, now residing in Coburg, Melbourne. A collection of 8mm home movies including:
Sword family life, including holidays in the 1970s
Fictional student films from Eaglehawk Primary, north of Bendigo
Melbourne scenes inlcuding Tullamarine Airport
School camp
Bendigo Show
Hanging Rock excursion
Moonee Ponds
Indonesia - Denpasar
Fellowship trip to the USA

results.title: [Korean artist] (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Begins with a resume of ancient Korean art. Then introduces the work of Lee Hyung Pyo, a contemporary Korean painter. Lee’s continuing artistic problem is to find a way of bridging the distance between the traditional culture into which he was born and the inescapable influences of the present.

results.title: [Kill Bill] Vol. 2
results.creator_credit: Quentin Tarantino, Lawrence Bender, A Band Apart and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: Volume two of The Bride’s (Uma Thurman) quest to exact revenge on those who prevented her from leaving the violent world of the hired killer. In “Kill Bill Vol. 1” The Bride is pregnant attending her wedding, when all are massacred and she is shot in the head leaving her in coma for four years. After recovering and killing the main perpetrators, she heads out in “Vol. 2” to find her mentor/ex-lover Bill (David Carradine) to kill him for ordering her assassination (and shooting her!). Fending off a few of his accomplices along the way, she battles these intense foes with the sword and anything else to hand. The Bride’s exceptional level of skill is not just hate-driven but substantiated in the teachings of a great master, Pai Mei (Gordon Liu). An homage to martial arts films from the East and West but still infused with the wit and humour of a Quentin Tarantino picture, “Kill Bill Vol. 2” is a classic revenge story with all of the requisite action sequences and fine storytelling. Cast includes Daryl Hannah, Michael Madsen, Michael Parks and Lucy Liu. WARNING: SOME SCENES MAY DISTURB.

results.title: [Kids' fun: a compilation of cartoon adventures]
results.creator_credit: Animafilm Studio, Castle Films and Romania Film
results.brief_description: A collection of Romanian and classic American animation. First up are four fun-filled Romanian cartoons designed for young children (Music and sound affects, no spoken words). The characters Michaela, Benny and Tommy are seen here having fun with all of their animal friends. Following is a collection of classic American cartoons made between the 1930’s and 1950’s including the first Heckle and Jeckle cartoon.

results.title: [George Malins Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a lovely history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

Note, the documentary ‘How I Filmed the War’ which is included in the collection was made by George’s uncle and official war photographer Geoffrey Malins. Geoffrey was awarded an OBE (Order of the British Empire) for his work in filming the ‘Battle of the Somme’.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

group_works.title: [Donald Duck in Matching Tricks; The Charging Bull]

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
It wasn’t just the Kodak factory in Coburg that produced amazing images during its hey-day. The then-industrial zone was also home to the Gadsden factory, which employed around 1000 workers in the 1960s, and specialised in can-making and packaging. The success of the business allowed two generations of Gadsden men, Stanley and his son Ronald, to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking – a relatively expensive hobby for the time.

We, and future generations, have benefited from their keen eye and passion for home movies, with a donation of films spanning the decades from the early 30s to the late 80s. The two cameramen captured the passage of time through their family, preserving a fascinating window into bygone days and customs.

Through the films we see early Melbourne, including some rare footage of a flooded Yarra River in the 1930s. Days at the beach, tennis, parties, interstate holidays and trips to the country have also been filmed, including a passion for skiing with many films in the collection featuring action both on the slopes and après–skiing at the lodge. You see the children growing up, the dapper fashions – a time when a dad and his kid in matching shirts was quite lovely.

The collection also contains a hidden gem, a short film labelled ‘de Groot’, which may be the only footage of the infamous Sydney Harbour Bridge Opening ribbon cutter – wielding a sword atop a horse, Francis de Groot declared the Bridge open to the horror of the officiating party. He was unexpected and uninvited!

This collection of home movies was originally made on 8mm and 16mm film.

results.title: [Fred Daley Collection]
results.material_description: 8mm home movie reels (small and large). Most already digitised.
results.brief_description:
A collection of silent, 8mm home movies by steam train enthusiast Fred Daley, capturing scenes of steam trains, the Daley family, vintage cars, railway stations, and snapshots of rural and city life.

The films are mainly shot on family holidays in various locations across Victoria from the City of Melbourne to Warburton, Apollo Bay and Mornington Peninsula, to a long road trip to Cooma, New South Wales. There is also a work specially dedicated to Victoria’s most famous steam train, Puffing Billy.

Fred was a skilled filmmaker - we are presented with polished films, employing use of a tripod, nifty title sequences and astute editing. Whilst filming steam trains was his passion, made evident by the many hours of footage dedicated to them, Fred also shows the family’s love of the outdoors on summer holidays, road trips, gardens, Luna Park, a game of football at the MCG, picnics and relaxing on the beach.

The titles shown here were made from the mid-to-late 1960s but Fred’s collection spans some fifty years. Kindly donated to the ACMI Collection by Fred’s son Neville, Fred’s Films provide memories not only for his family but also for the collective memory of Victorians, steam train buffs, filmmakers, historians, or anyone who has the pleasure of watching them.

A collection of silent home movies filmed by train enthusiast Fred Daley.
Footage of:
Daley Family
Steam trains
Vintage cars
Railway stations
Family holidays
Locations across Victoria
Warburton
Echuca
Heathcote
Mornington
Tasmania
Alice Springs

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movie Collection]
results.material_description: 1 x DVD, 8mm, 16mm home movies and a 35mm film strip.
results.brief_description: The Douglas Wilson Home Movie Collection contains home movies, originally made on 8mm and 16mm film, showing life in Australia in the 1950s and 1960s. Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

results.title: [Eat LOUD carpet compilation]
results.creator_credit: LOUD Media Festival of Youth Culture and the Arts
results.brief_description: A collection of four short films from the SBS program, “Eat Carpet”, in which things aren’t always as they seem. “Goth to be Greek”, directed by Andrew Georgiou and Tim Slade, is the story of a goth who finally finds a woman who wears black and hangs out in cemeteries. “Bad news”, directed by Sofya Gollan, tells the tale of a profoundly deaf couple who react in an unexpected way after hearing some news from their apologetic doctor. “Skater, homie, skeggy, wog”, directed by Andrew Dowell and Brendan Dowell, focuses on some of the myths and misconceptions that teens from rival suburbs have regarding each other’s dress and way of living. “How black is black?”, directed by Jade Woods (aged 13), looks at the identity crises suffered by fair-skinned Koories.
